claim: Food and drink have become more affordable in Britain since 1950.

supporting.text: The average real income in Britain has increased significantly since 1950, making food and drink relatively more affordable for most households.

attacks.text: The average real income in Britain has increased significantly since 1950, making food and drink relatively more affordable for most households.
While real incomes have risen, food prices have also increased disproportionately due to inflation and supply chain disruptions, offsetting affordability gains.
Inflation-adjusted data shows that food price increases have been slower than income growth, maintaining relative affordability.
Income inequality has widened since 1950, meaning affordability gains are concentrated among higher-income households, not 'most households'.
Even with inequality, median real income growth ensures the majority of households experience improved food affordability.
Essential non-food costs (housing, utilities) have risen faster than incomes, reducing disposable income available for food and drink.

supporting.text: Technological advancements in agriculture and food production have reduced costs, leading to lower prices for food and drink in Britain since 1950.

attacks.text: Technological advancements in agriculture and food production have reduced costs, leading to lower prices for food and drink in Britain since 1950.
While production costs have decreased, inflation and other economic factors have offset these savings, leading to higher consumer prices.
Inflation-adjusted data shows that food prices have indeed decreased relative to average income since 1950, supporting the original claim.
The benefits of technological advancements have been unevenly distributed, with some food and drink items becoming more expensive due to increased demand for premium products.
Even premium products have seen cost reductions in production, though their prices may remain high due to branding and marketing strategies.

supporting.text: The expansion of global trade and supply chains since 1950 has increased the availability and reduced the cost of imported food and drink in Britain.

attacks.text: The expansion of global trade and supply chains since 1950 has increased the availability and reduced the cost of imported food and drink in Britain.
While global trade has increased availability, it has also introduced volatility in food prices due to geopolitical instability and climate change affecting supply chains.
Britain's reliance on imports has made food prices sensitive to currency fluctuations, such as the devaluation of the pound, which can increase costs despite trade expansion.
Domestic food production has declined due to cheaper imports, reducing self-sufficiency and potentially increasing long-term costs if trade disruptions occur.
Technological advancements in agriculture and logistics have mitigated some risks of trade dependency, maintaining stable prices despite import reliance.
The environmental and social costs of long-distance food transport (e.g., carbon emissions, labor exploitation) are not reflected in retail prices, masking true affordability.

supporting.text: Government policies and subsidies in Britain since 1950 have helped stabilize food prices, contributing to greater affordability.

attacks.text: Government policies and subsidies in Britain since 1950 have helped stabilize food prices, contributing to greater affordability.
While subsidies stabilize prices, inflation-adjusted data shows that food costs relative to income have risen in some periods, undermining the claim of consistent affordability.
Subsidies disproportionately benefit large agribusinesses, leading to market distortions that can raise consumer prices in the long term.
Global supply chain disruptions and Brexit-related trade barriers have increased food costs in Britain, counteracting subsidy effects.
Post-Brexit price spikes are temporary and do not negate the long-term trend of affordability enabled by subsidies.

supporting.text: The proportion of household income spent on food and drink in Britain has decreased since 1950, indicating increased affordability.

attacks.text: The proportion of household income spent on food and drink in Britain has decreased since 1950, indicating increased affordability.
The decrease in proportion spent on food and drink could be due to rising incomes rather than falling prices, meaning affordability may not have improved.
Even with rising incomes, the relative cost of food and drink has decreased, as evidenced by lower price indices adjusted for inflation.
Changes in dietary habits and increased consumption of processed foods may skew the proportion spent, not reflecting true affordability of basic staples.
Historical data shows that both processed and unprocessed food categories have seen relative price declines, supporting broader affordability.

supporting.text: The rise of supermarkets and large retail chains since 1950 has driven competition and lowered prices for food and drink in Britain.

attacks.text: The rise of supermarkets and large retail chains since 1950 has driven competition and lowered prices for food and drink in Britain.
While supermarkets have lowered prices, inflation-adjusted data shows that food and drink prices have risen in real terms since 1950 due to increased production and distribution costs.
Supermarkets often engage in price wars, which temporarily lower prices, but long-term affordability is influenced by broader economic factors like wages and inflation.
The dominance of supermarkets has also led to the decline of small local shops, reducing consumer choice and potentially increasing prices in areas with limited competition.
Local shops often charge higher prices due to lower economies of scale, so their decline does not necessarily indicate reduced affordability overall.
